9EF0232104DB4AB78E73B2D92B3CCEB6.description: Research a famous playwright or dramatic work.

588FB369F859401ABEAB60828DAEAF52.description: Explore a variety of theatrical works that were performed during the Renaissance

5FB03531AB6142F0BA56E1D1C41598FF.description: Discuss how theatre evolved throughout the Renaissance in Europe and England

070654BC02E840BAA804D6B8B2C25E65.description: Investigate traditions or stories from Canadian communities as an inspiration for creating dramatizations

7F8C97319A6649D1B5DF9FEEAD1DECAB.description: Observe dramatic works from modern-day professional theatre companies

0923C52FCDB04F3A9A2A0B03B9F09C13.description: Explore the narrative of a heroic epic as an inspiration for creating dramatizations

F7A206D5054F491C977A150694E4146D.description: Drama went through a significant change during the Renaissance and the Protestant Reformation

CEE144BC68A7410CAED689423BBEA390.description: Drama in colonial Canada was reflective of the changes that occurred in Europe at the same time

40C62ADD6A04458C82EFC1C602DCCBA8.description: Drama has changed over time as communities and cultures have evolved.

3247872D2D80410AB807A977503E848B.description: In 1642, many theatres and playhouses were shut down or burned down because some religious groups believed that drama was an inappropriate art form.

22AF325D77DF4CCEAC39CB3CCD8E7854.description: Famous playwrights who emerged and influenced drama during the Renaissance include Shakespeare (1564-1616), an English playwright, poet, and actor considered one of the greatest writers of the English language Jean-Baptiste Poquelin (1622-1673), a French playwright, actor, and poet known by the stage name Moliere and considered one of the greatest writers of the French language

97D5828BB7774087A9F5A27119D83E10.description: During the Renaissance in England, theatres became public venues where all social classes could come together and enjoy performances.

44FEA9BF8E504464AE184BD769464FCD.description: The thrust stage was developed during the Elizabethan period to bring the action closer to the common people, while the upper class sat in elevated boxes, as seen in Shakespeare's Globe Theatre

5DAEA17D87DB49FBAEE28C56A70AE8A4.description: Elizabethan theatre took place primarily outdoors in theatres, including the courtyards of inns The Rose Theatre The Curtain The Globe Theatre

9C7FAF5FA4274DF094B9E82D0A2301B8.description: Elizabethan theatre performances were less informed by classical Roman influence and more informed by what was popular with British audiences

71FFF35D68264FCD99A431F6D2447279.description: The term Elizabethan emerged from the English Renaissance to reflect the style of performance that was popular during the reign of Queen Elizabeth I (1558-1603)

AF69EF43021F41B6AFB638CEB29F0503.description:
In 1517, the Protestant Reformation influenced traditional Renaissance views on arts and theatre, which included plays that gave actors more work with less emphasis on
religion

172BF49794CD406585C32BB48057FBAA.description: Commedia dell-arte influenced the development of modern-day musical theatre, opera, and improvisational comedy.

14907137FB5D426FB96591C35EFF15C0.description: Commedia dell-arte was developed as a form of clowning in Italy during the Renaissance and used stock characters to develop improvisational and scripted scenes.

CA680A53EC644CD0B21FF0A3ADFC60B6.description: The Teatro Olimpico is a Palladian theatre that still exists in Vincenza, Italy, today

0F739C1386944D0C912507B953BCBFC6.description: Before the construction of the Palladian theatre, dramatizations were performed on simple outdoor stages with only curtains for a backdrop.

4374BE21C225468CBCE92D0617356C60.description: The construction of Palladian theatres allowed for more elaborate scenes and sets to be used and influenced modern-day theatres

9D0FC62CBB3147A08620F2FECFF1376E.description: Palladian theatres were designed by the architect Palladio, and were the first indoor theatres to exist during the Renaissance

A71B55BC1A2747519614FB36B56E6318.description: Mystery plays were dramatizations based on bible stories that were commonly performed at church or at celebrations such as religious festivals

FDEB033D55C44982808A36D9CA5EC69D.description: Plays about morality during the European Renaissance evolved out of mystery plays from the Middle Ages.

578328BCCB8D4B4B9BAF7AE0D1C17B0B.description: The Renaissance era was about all people bettering themselves through education, literature, science, and the arts

E30E2FB4470E48C2BC7ADC5EDBA1E0BA.description: Stories told through drama in Canadian communities could be linked to a person's place of origin

63E236F177AD4836AFBC75820537EE5E.description: First Nations, Métis, and Inuit storytelling and languages were banned by Canadian government policies in colonial Canada.

42FADB40732345489131A6E046E1034B.description: Non-professional theatre in colonial Canada influenced modern Francophone professional theatre companies.

68D5004A67A04FB6ADB1D7C603462048.description: Non-professional (amateur) drama evolved into a professional theatrical art form in colonial Canada.

B1E243F673C447759CF0BCFACDEC4C42.description: As more people immigrated to Canada from various parts of the world, they brought with them the dramatic traditions and cultures of their homelands

46FE6DF01F3C405AB1AE2161CF06452D.description: Professional actors began to arrive in colonial Canada from Europe and the Thirteen Colonies during the great migration (1815-1850)

8B1B859A2C054929AEB5DF4B3FE8C7D6.description: Heroic epic was used to retell the story of the Battle of the Plains of Abraham

5915EB7122EA4E228965046C1AF6BFE5.description: Heroic epics originated in ancient Greece and continue to be used in drama today

B4E845B19C28487DA175659DAAE2837B.description: An epic is a long, narrative poem that reflects the heroic actions of a person or group of people in a certain time and place

3F8C2E7413B14FC580FA9E6F77A57F82.description: Literary styles such as heroic epic were reflected in the drama and theatre of colonial Canada

623136FD289045A98647E9768A5A02D9.description: European and French playwrights inspired the subject matter of theatre in colonial Canada.

0E7F2BF1833646B3BFF8A03EF998B28F.description: Students investigate how changes in past societies have influenced the creation and sharing of drama.

908E3A3A66EE4413A73E4CAB335F3F39.description: Appreciation: Recognizing beauty, goodness, and truth in drama can be developed by understanding the complexity and richness of great dramatic works, the artists who create and perform them, and the historical and cultural contexts from which they originate

EA30B78EDF484293AB9A4781E0F5709D.description: Participate as an audience member and as a performer in drama

2F6AA3EB6CFB40BCA280C342A8221443.description: Demonstrate how to follow staging cues when clarifying positions and movement of performers in a narrative

6263ED447B114E54AB4C8B889DE028FF.description: Experiment with the possibilities of the voice and the body in communication of a narrative

BBC95AF5350B479C9C51AE2A125B1612.description: Describe how feedback about the narrative was incorporated.

D6C2A1E5E21E4217BB13DBFB28317C93.description: Express a character's status through role play

7CB4068E376F4AEFB20739A37C146CF7.description: Make artistic choices in the creation of a narrative

8E5E245AE0A4436BB60151A5DFAE12CE.description: Explore narratives in First Nations, Métis, or Inuit storytelling

D060A07653EC4FCFB2C8ADA6F7B82C30.description: Perform invented or scripted dramas based on a narrative

E55D57AEC46E441486669C6CA1050781.description: Choose a topic to communicate through a narrative

B4BCED02434540EA9FEF7EC9F578FDAD.description: Explore how the use of technical elements can enhance the structure of a narrative

C10E209FC15B4279B89CD8C29EBE1C1F.description: Experiment with improvisation as a way to structure a narrative

7F7C70949FD1488D9BD654D6E06C4E13.description: Create a plan for structuring a narrative

E5AB14C9119146EF956255971B0A45F1.description: A narrative may be perceived by an audience in a way that differs from what the performer intended

9FFAC067DA0D48A492AA18CA8ED8F613.description: A narrative can take an audience on a journey by entertaining and persuading

C1F638D9093642A0BFD883FA880A85C9.description: The exploration of a culture's narrative through drama can help the viewer to build cultural understanding

F11CF44AA98C432EAED7281F19A024CC.description: A narrative can communicate knowledge and understandings about the world

65BAE2A6425E41C1B1272C96743F36D9.description: A narrative can be structured to describe the past, the present, or the future

E9D657754D1849378660069CE1E77435.description: Audience participation can enhance how a narrative is communicated in drama.

45222B5A15B94D3695FEEE6E789C3425.description: Feedback from an audience can influence future performances

4796AE5E8A724534880577600943D3C5.description: Status can change depending on how the body and voice is used

15AC637BA0964684A522784D70886BA1.description: Status is the level of importance or power that a character holds in relation to other characters

14EE46652E6946AD92451F50CCC6E31A.description: A character's status or feelings can be communicated and enhanced through narrative

21EC6A62A8F74E69BC220A0B5E61A640.description: Artistic choices can revise and re imagine how a narrative is expressed and can include the use of voice body dramatic forms technical elements staging

C57790D5A0DA4C3CAF4149E4BCB7EEA8.description: Narrative in First Nations, Métis, and Inuit storytelling can originate from the land and include the wind water soil animals plants

D84F8D1FC62D43B890BEEF33EBF498A1.description: Narrative can be expressed in First Nations, Métis, and Inuit stories and can be witnessed through the spirit or life of the storyteller

A8E640C79DB7487C8869354D38D4EB73.description: A narrative is represented in diverse ways across cultures

4430275B48F74764968E7699CB73D1AD.description: There are universal themes that can occur in narratives, including redemption survival quest

903AFE4C089E43CCADFFA42FDE64022F.description: A narrative can be based on stories, legends, myths, and poetry fictional or non-fictional events characters individuals or communities historical or cultural events

74978DBB160645468BA0D9180774C6A7.description: Narrative can be planned or improvised.

97DE9C41A71547CBAC499CF49894F4DE.description: Dramatic forms can be used to structure how a narrative is told

B5E1076CCEBA44A9997FA92E4EEF1BDD.description: Narrative can be represented individually or collectively.

DACCEB2FFAA54F5D9E31AE35703E35F5.description: Technical elements applied to staging can enhance how a narrative is represented

8A4E2F7B44CD4ED1BD06118CDF4198B8.description: Staging considerations can influence representation of a narrative

9F97BB842399407484419279EA68A475.description: Parts of a narrative may be excluded, leaving the audience to assume what happened before and after the narrative was presented

E64D53F29D8F48768CE71786B2586A5C.description: Dramatic tension in a narrative can build suspense and can give the audience something to anticipate

4A756DE0FFAB4B678BD18C57420BF834.description: The structure of a narrative can include a beginning, a problem, and a resolution.

6D1C580B74DF437390848C905D60DE4C.description: Students represent narratives based on a variety of inspirations and through the application of artistic choices

3A75FE83D3C84B2CB699229F922908D1.description: Creating and Presenting: Ideas can be represented dramatically through artworks that draw upon foundational knowledge

64D946FD56404D8593E5DF39947AAEA2.description: Discuss the effectiveness of technical elements used in a dramatization

883BC368B3294D9DB97244E1C755B88E.description: Explore the effects that technical elements have in a dramatization.

1822DCD4C7D5468E860C3FCDCE45655C.description: Explore the effects that body positions can have on dramatic expression

551F360C33664A11B0CF3F857DB3B58D.description: Explore how blocking can contribute to presentations in drama

E2D482343B754283A324DB6E591BE0E5.description: Implement changes to a particular area to create a performance space

252B97CF1AEF4561B776F4EC2F8D7381.description: Identify various ways an audience can participate in a drama

10D3A7180F73431F8FBAF16F2814EDE8.description: Explore how tension in the body and breath can influence vocal quality

90838DBE0B2D48448FD81EB370235DDF.description: Discuss how proper body and vocal warm-ups can contribute to dramatic expression.

2C2242261AD24972A74EA6A6F7C857B6.description: Participate in various ways to warm up the body and voice

0B6BAB4407B148EA9BFFECC240CBB25A.description: Explore how vocal release is dependent on body and breath

3689DA9A505F45A3828AAE27BA9F69EE.description: Experiment with how the voice can shape the development of a character or situation

5237E8C2E6754D3F9B8E846E72FA7F21.description: Explore the use of articulators in adjusting vocal sounds.

A41141A3336C45448E08161C2AF91841.description: Differentiate between stereotypes and authentic character.

116E5796D99F44458929CA92862459C9.description: Experiment with how the voice can create a variety of sounds.

6DC160E62FE348AA812A7DBA67717EE7.description: Staging includes technical elements that can enhance a dramatization

B5C0AEFC10CF4BDCB7F71775530192DB.description: Staging reflects the relationship between the audience and performer(s) within a performance space

2A301EB05B1540BFB065CC16C8729B0C.description: Staging supports expression in dramatic performances

3E832B97DDBC4BD096660D4D2535BE79.description: Any space can be transformed into a performance space

A599C2E9C57040FF86CBA24F2019A5A8.description: The voice functions optimally when warmed up, exercised, and relaxed.

3E2CD6F16B4B481F87E1077858C759E9.description: The voice is released from the body with an appropriate amount of breath for the space, idea, and feeling

4B83E505C58741A79F3A75B6115CA53F.description: The voice conveys a performer's intention in the way that it is used

801B853312A5473EA0466B01340649D2.description: The voice has a natural and distinguishable tone that can represent the uniqueness of an individual

FDF700936F0A4C35905F4D830CA983CB.description: The voice is an expressive instrument that is capable of producing and reproducing sound

44D26CD0FED2416A919C3B38C8C85278.description: Technical elements can influence an audience's experience of a dramatization

6BAC9070BAA442618DDBC304DC260ADF.description: Technical elements can be added to a performance to clarify ideas for an audience, and can include costumes props sounds sets lighting

28AE8348D0BD4EFB911C027FD2D3CBA7.description: Staging can enhance a dramatization through the use of movement or stillness light or dark sound or silence

A63ED7CD12234071B52E65556E1AB295.description: Audiences may engage in a performance in a variety of ways, including singing using props verbally answering questions from the performer(s) suggesting ideas

2342713FA90447EB93EEA75DFB2697D3.description: A dramatization may include the audience as a participant in the performance

970A849693A743518AEC13D0D99F4218.description: Not all dramatic forms can be staged in the same way

6085C60B724A435881CB1833119809C7.description: Body positions on stage can include full front, profile, and full back

CBC8D2DDFB71410DB16625B9DD18AD58.description: Blocking is a performer's movement and positioning on stage that can influence expression

5DCC9CBE52BE424382B7CBCB82BD60F5.description: Staging considerations include optimal audibility and visibility for an audience

E5C64CE46D44483EA79D63EB1CD31F47.description: Staging includes the movement of actors and objects in a performance space

49453FC5135A4244A8048F54E139801E.description: Tension in the body and breath affects how the voice expresses thought and feeling.

2BE042C7BB1143B39595412F437FCCD2.description: Vocal warm-ups for drama can include exercises for breath control pitch variation projection articulation

6F3B93D5C43547858380FD255DF7C803.description: Physical warm-ups for drama can include stretching extensions breath exercises cardiovascular exercise

F8C39013D7F74C34A5F3929853DFC4E6.description: Stage whispers require an excess release of breath to project the voice effectively.

659C9A2A896C470BB0BAA2F6D76899C2.description: The amount of breath used in vocal production will vary according to the performance space.

60D619161C1D472FBBED3BAFE550681A.description: The voice can represent the perspective of the character

C613F34F512E4DA892CB7602CFB749A8.description: The voice can be used to represent thoughts feelings experiences imagination personal attributes

24D1FD49DE524EACA9F664399C343A2E.description: The voice is what is heard, felt, and imagined by an audience.

FC085A0978C34CBEB3C9EB444CCB73C3.description: The articulators contribute to producing clear sounds and words and can be developed through vocal exercises, including tongue twisters

171802753A73426EABBA86D019915A05.description: Articulators are vocal organs in the body that influence sound and can include the lips teeth tongue hard pallet soft pallet

D5D6B93ECD044FC1944E25DC6B6A31A1.description: An authentic character is an accurate and genuine representation of a person

80D3A8DEEC8B4C5482D80854B3CE0E19.description: Stereotypes in drama are collections of personality traits or generalizations of what a character sounds like or looks like.

2A1C029B06E24DC7821582C4A797B5F1.description: The voice and the body can reflect stereotypes and characters in drama

325B6F4B60FE42E78EC54BEAC786469A.description: Production of the voice includes vocal pitch energy tone volume projection articulation phrasing pace

57912AF3BC924AC6983E22A8F034596A.description: Tone of voice includes volume emphasis accent intonation

87ACD31C2B86436FBC609BEEF54D410B.description: Students investigate voice and staging as a means of expression in drama.

9D281B1871B0407DA075F67C14EAC82A.description: Foundational Elements: Drama literacy is developed through knowledge and application of dramatic processes.
